Made an OpenTable reservation for four at Blue Plate during restaurant week. We were seated at a table in a front nook - a bit of a tight fit, but cozy and a nicely secluded spot. From the restaurant week menu, we ordered: - ahi tuna deviled eggs - black truffle gnocchi - fried chicken - chocolate panna cotta Everything was delicious, but the gnocchi and fried chicken were the standouts. The gnocchi is served with a generous heaping of ricotta, squash, and aleppo crumbs add a nice crunch. So decadent. The fried chicken is boneless and melts in your mouth. The pomegranate arugula salad it's served with provides some contrast. Mashed potatoes are creamy. This was some of the better fried chicken I've ever had. Highly recommend. All in all - an upscale option in Bernal heights with great food and good vibes. Can't wait to come back!

Great place for traditional American fare. It was, unfortunately, a somewhat gloomy day when my wife and I went, otherwise it would have been great to sit in their cute little garden/patio area. All the food was great, particularly the fried chicken. And their key lime pie might have been the absolute best I've ever had!!

We came here for my friends birthday dinner on sat, she was able to grab reservations a week before for 7 people ! Parking isn't too difficult to find around here, i found parking around the block and it was less than a 2 min. walk. Blue plate is not a traditional restaurant setup, it is located in what seems to be a house. It is very narrow, and homey feeling inside, everyone is sort of squished but it never feels like you don't have enough space. We ordered the goat cheese mac n cheese, burrata, black truffle gnocchi, crispy octopus , smoked filet mignon bruschetta ( 2 pieces) for appetizers. I enjoyed the gnocchi, octopus, and the smoked filet mignon bruschetta the most. The gnocchi had a nice crispy part and yummy truffle flavor. The octopus was so tender, you could cut it with a fork! The bruschetta with filet mignon was so tasty and tender too, but it was a little pricey for this dish $13, for 2 small pieces of bread. For the main dishes we ordered 2 egg tagliorini, duck confit, fried chicken, blue plate meatloaf, and the hangar steak. The main dishes here are pretty big, and you can probably share with 1 other person if you also order an appetizer. My favorites were the tagliorini and the fried chicken. The tagliorini was so freaking flavorful, and tasted light but when you looked at the bottom of the dish there was a huge pool of oil, so probably not as light as it tasted. The fried chicken here is boneless and so tender, it wasn't too salty and so so crispy. The service here is super friendly and welcoming, the food also came out pretty quickly considering how busy they were. Great place for dinner with friends, it was really loud so I wouldn't suggest coming here for a first date.

Went to Blue Plate Friday night for vday. What. a. meal. When we first arrived the staff was slammed and running behind. We awkwardly huddled at the front for 15 minutes or so before we were seated. Smooth sailing from that point on. We brought our own bottle of Pinot for a corkage fee of $25. This is a nice option if you have a stocked wine fridge (like me). We started off with complimentary focaccia. It was heavenly. Soft, pillowy focaccia with a hint of salt. We loved it. Next up was the filet mignon bruschetta and salad with citrus. Both tasted very complex and flavorful. For the main course we had a short rib and chicken thighs. The short rib with the root mash was excellent. The chicken thighs were also tasty. To finish we had the cranberry lime pie and the semifreddo. The pie was heavenly. I have never tasted a better pie. Can't wait to come back and explore more dishes!

So there I was perusing the SF dining week list and I had remembered a conversation that I was having with my boss. He strongly recommended this place as a good alternative for the hustle and bustle of most swanky restaurants in the Mission. In short - my expectations were exceeded significantly and the food was awesome. Let's start off with the apps. The wife and I ordered the filet mignon brushetta and black truffle gnocchi. The bruschetta was awesome and surprisingly light and kinda reminding me of a mini pastrami sandwich. The gnocchi was phenomenal and surprisingly balanced with stronger notes of lemon. Then the mains came out. The wife opted for the egg tagliorini and I the fried chicken. I liked the tagliorini after the gnocchi, didn't have the palate for more pasta, but the wife loves artichoke and it was right up her alley. The chicken pieces were boneless thigh and the batter was crisp without being super oily, but is was the buttermilk ranch pairing really pushed it over the edge. To polish it all off, we ordered a slice of key lime pie, which has an absolutely amazing Graham cracker crust, and the butterscotch pudding, which was too rich for my taste. The only downside was that this place was absolutely slammed and understaffed, so it took a while for us to get service. I don't blame the poor waiter, he was serving almost 10 tables by himself and looked super stressed. I'll be back again to try more. It's definitely will executed food with being pretentious.

Came here with family from out of town, went home and promptly booked a meal with friends for New Years Eve. For starters, the space is relaxed and unassuming, with warm, pleasantly insouciant decor. After entering what was seemingly a cozy small front room, we were surprised to discover an expansive back room and patio; this probably explains why it's actually possible to get a reservation just a few days in advance. Blue plate is a true homage to the splendid elasticity of both American and Mediterranean cuisines. As previous reviews have indicated, the fried chicken is fantastic. This is not the "get out your wet-naps" oily kind of fried chicken - the skin is tremendously crunchy, the breading hardy but not overwhelming, envelops the perfectly moist chicken underneath. Another favorite were the ahi tuna tartare deviled eggs. They were so unique, and not too rich; an excellent sharing plate. Friends have also felt the duck confit was delicious. The GM/owner (I think) Shannon is fantastic - it really feels like you're in her home with her family (across the board, the staff is wonderful) any time we're there. So grateful to have found this hidden gem in Bernal, working on regular-status in the months to come!

I am here for the Blue Plate special that is the restaurant known as Blue Plate, which has been serving traditional homespun American fare in the Outer Mission area of San Francisco for over twenty years. I have wanted to try Blue Plate for some time now and finally got the opportunity when a group of friends and I all agreed that for Restaurant Week 2019, this was the place to try out with their options of Hangar Steak, Fried Chicken and their signature Meatloaf dish as their entree options for the SFRW 2019 pre-fix option, we were sold, as very few other restaurants were offering this many proteins to select from as their dinner options. Blue Plate is located in an area where parking was tough, even late on a Sunday evening when I tried to make reservations for four people, which thankfully after I spoke with their fantastic host Shannon she managed to move up my scheduled reservation via OpenTable up one hour to 7:30 p.m. The first thing that you notice about Blue Plate is the diner vibe in the main dining room with its sleek counter top and intimate mood lighting, and the fact that it is very cramped in said dining room once you open their front door and check in with the aforementioned Shannon. We thankfully we placed in one of their back dining rooms, which seemed little lived in with their narrow corridors, but nicely overlooked their outdoor garden patio area. We of course were here for the SF Restaurant Week menu and with a variety of options we were down for sampling almost everything on their menu. Our first course was to order all four options: the Butternut Squash Soup topped with herb croutons and black truffle oil, the Smoked Beets and Burrata mixed with winter chicories, fennel, crispy quinoa (which tasted a little too charred for my taste) and topped with Cardamom Vinaigrette, the Toasted Farro with a Slow Egg with porcini, parmesan, meyer lemon pistou and served with two slices of toasted bread. My favorite of their small plates was the Brandade Gnocchi topped with duck confit, cranberry, preserved lemon and aleppo breadcrumb which was a creamy yet heavy delight full of flavor. It was easily the richest dish I was going to have all night long. Thankfully, I had plenty of water to wash down my meal as the complimentary fresh foccacia bread was too salty for my taste. Before we even decided to share in those appetizers, I managed to check in on my Yelp app on my phone and the check -in deal was a complimentary Deviled Egg appetizer, I promptly showed one of the servers and I was expecting to get one Deviled Egg to sample, but imagine my surprise when our server eventually showed up with four Deviled Eggs on a plate, perfectly seasoned and playfully presented with radishes and edible flowers as a garnish, this was a lovely surprise to be treated to in this culinary experience. As for our main courses, all four of us knew we wanted the three major protein entrees, among them the Grilled Hanger Steak served with panzanella, romesco, cippolini onion and ruby red mustard greens; their signature Fried Chicken served with a pomegranate arugula salad and smoked jalapeno buttermilk dressing for dipping; and their signature Blue Plate Meatloaf served with mashed potatoes and blue lake green beans. The Fried Chicken was juicy yet still crispy delight, and the meatloaf, although relatively plain ingredients-wise, was moist and flavorful. I was so glad I ordered the Hanger Steak, which as usual was the belly cut of the cow that hangs really low hence the name, cooked medium just the way I like it and served with its own juicy marinade and plenty of fresh veggies like onions and greens. It was a feast for the eyes and mouth thanks the amount of food that was on my plate and how well prepared the dish was. We were all thoroughly satisfied after feasting on our entrees. But of course we still had our dessert course to go, with choices of their Key Lime Pie, Chocolate Hazelnut Semifreddo, and their Butterscotch Pudding with Pecan Brittle, I went with the latter while others opted for the pie, the dessert chef was so frazzled with so many orders all night long thanks to their pre-fix dining deal that he left us with five desserts, two pies, two puddings and one semifreddo despite only being four of us at our table. Talk about taking the extra steps to make sure we were all full! I loved the hint of booze in my butterscotch pudding which was perfectly presented and not too sweet, as were the pie and semifreddo which was a fun spin on an ice cream cake with whipped cream. Blue Plate you made our Restaurant Week experience one to remember. Great service and a solid variety of food at affordable prices set in an old-school atmosphere. I can't wait to return to try some dishes off of their a la carte menu, thanks to SFRW, we got a great sample of at least three of their six large plates that and their variety of smaller plates makes me want to come back for more!

I wish I had snapped photos of my food because it was all so good!!! We ordered the pork belly, the steak, octopus and a couple of other tasty/eye catching items. All of it was delicious, my two friends who drove up from San Jose love the restaurant. We sat outside in this beautiful oasis underneath trees and the lighting was soft yet perfect. Staff was super rad and attentive even sitting outside. Definitely come here and try to remember to take a photo before diving in! I'll be back! Omg so yummy!

Our first week in the bay area, we decided to check out Blue Plate on a recommendation from a coworker to celebrate and congratulate ourselves on a move well-finished. We were a bit late thanks to a delay on BART, but when we told the hostess that we had a reservation and were running late, we were still seated immediately. We were greeted quickly by our waiter, Cal, who was very friendly and personable with an approachable character that put us immediately at ease, and had us laughing and joking around even before we started drinking. He made perfect wine recommendations, and when I requested a sweeter Pinot, he recommended two different bottles. The one we chose based on his recommendation was perfect. We ordered two appetizers (Brandade Gnocchi and Smoked Beets and Burrata), two entrees (Hangar Steak and Meatloaf), two side dishes (Macaroni and Spanish Drunken Goat Cheese and the Brussels Sprouts), and split a Key Lime Pie for dessert.Blue Plate also serves homemade Focaccia bread while you order and wait for your meals. Focaccia: We honestly could have just ordered a bottle of wine and eaten our fill of the focaccia, it was so good. In fact, I blame this for us not being able to finish our meals when they arrived - but I would absolutely do it again. Brandade Gnocchi: The gnocchi in this dish were perfectly light and fluffy, and the duck confit had a great flavor and complemented the dish well. Absolutely delicious. Smoked Beets and Burrata: I loved this dish, though beets are hit or miss for my partner and he didn't enjoy it. The smoked beets were hands down the best beets I had ever eaten, and the buratta and greens helped immensely to cut through the smokiness. Hangar Steak: The steak was cooked perfectly to medium rare as I had requested, and the romesco sauce and greens were very fresh and complemented the steak well. Meatloaf: Hands down the best meatloaf I've ever tasted. I was a bit skeptical of this dish, because I've never loved meatloaf, but when I tried my partners, I was absolutely blown away. The accompanying mashed potatoes were also perfectly light and smooth. Macaroni and Spanish Drunken Goat Cheese: Besides being scorching hot - of which we were warned - this macaroni and cheese was perfectly balanced, and was a great side. Brussels Sprouts: I originally expected the eggplant to be in pieces with the brussels sprouts, but instead they were pureed with the tasso and honey into the sauce which adorned the plate, and actually provided a great foil to the sprouts. Not at all what I was expecting, but great! Key Lime Pie: One of my favorite desserts anyway, this key lime pie was amazing. It wasn't overwhelming with key lime flavor like many store-bought or food-service brand key lime pies, instead opting for a more mellow flavor, and a much lighter custard filling. Word to the wise, the portions are relatively large for the appetizers and entrees. We could have done with only one appetizer, or only one side, and we had to take some of our meals home at the end of the night - not entirely a bad thing, since we're now munching through them with our breakfast the next morning! We will definitely be back!

    1 photo

    Came here with family from out of town, went home and promptly booked a meal with friends for New Years Eve.  For starters, the space is relaxed and unassuming, with warm, pleasantly insouciant decor.  After entering what was seemingly a cozy small front room, we were surprised to discover an expansive back room and patio; this probably explains why it's actually possible to get a reservation just a few days in advance.

    Blue plate is a true homage to the splendid elasticity of both American and Mediterranean cuisines.  As previous reviews have indicated, the fried chicken is fantastic.  This is not the "get out your wet-naps" oily kind of fried chicken - the skin is tremendously crunchy, the breading hardy but not overwhelming, envelops the perfectly moist chicken underneath.  Another favorite were the ahi tuna tartare deviled eggs.  They were so unique, and not too rich; an excellent sharing plate.  Friends have also felt the duck confit was delicious.

    The GM/owner (I think) Shannon is fantastic - it really feels like you're in her home with her family (across the board, the staff is wonderful) any time we're there.  

    So grateful to have found this hidden gem in Bernal, working on regular-status in the months to come!

    East Bay, CA
    1250 friends
    585 reviews
    15952 photos

    Elite '2020

    Share review

    Embed review

    1/29/2019

    17 photos

    1 check-in

    I am here for the Blue Plate special that is the restaurant known as Blue Plate, which has been serving traditional homespun American fare in the Outer Mission area of San Francisco for over twenty years. I have wanted to try Blue Plate for some time now and finally got the opportunity when a group of friends and I all agreed that for Restaurant Week 2019, this was the place to try out with their options of Hangar Steak, Fried Chicken and their signature Meatloaf dish as their entree options for the SFRW 2019 pre-fix option, we were sold, as very few other restaurants were offering this many proteins to select from as their dinner options. Blue Plate is located in an area where parking was tough, even late on a Sunday evening when I tried to make reservations for four people, which thankfully after I spoke with their fantastic host Shannon she managed to move up my scheduled reservation via OpenTable up one hour to 7:30 p.m.

    The first thing that you notice about Blue Plate is the diner vibe in the main dining room with its sleek counter top and intimate mood lighting, and the fact that it is very cramped in said dining room once you open their front door and check in with the aforementioned Shannon. We thankfully we placed in one of their back dining rooms, which seemed little lived in with their narrow corridors, but nicely overlooked their outdoor garden patio area. We of course were here for the SF Restaurant Week menu and with a variety of options we were down for sampling almost everything on their menu. Our first course was to order all four options: the Butternut Squash Soup topped with herb croutons and black truffle oil, the Smoked Beets and Burrata mixed with winter chicories, fennel, crispy quinoa (which tasted a little too charred for my taste) and topped with Cardamom Vinaigrette, the Toasted Farro with a Slow Egg with porcini, parmesan, meyer lemon pistou and served with two slices of toasted bread. My favorite of their small plates was the Brandade Gnocchi topped with duck confit, cranberry, preserved lemon and aleppo breadcrumb which was a creamy yet heavy delight full of flavor. It was easily the richest dish I was going to have all night long. Thankfully, I had plenty of water to wash down my meal as the complimentary fresh foccacia bread was too salty for my taste.

    Before we even decided to share in those appetizers, I managed to check in on my Yelp app on my phone and the check -in deal was a complimentary Deviled Egg appetizer, I promptly showed one of the servers and I was expecting to get one Deviled Egg to sample, but imagine my surprise when our server eventually showed up with four Deviled Eggs on a plate, perfectly seasoned and playfully presented with radishes and edible flowers as a garnish, this was a lovely surprise to be treated to in this culinary experience. As for our main courses, all four of us knew we wanted the three major protein entrees, among them the Grilled Hanger Steak served with panzanella, romesco, cippolini onion and ruby red mustard greens; their signature Fried Chicken served with a pomegranate arugula salad and smoked jalapeno buttermilk dressing for dipping; and their signature Blue Plate Meatloaf served with mashed potatoes and blue lake green beans. The Fried Chicken was juicy yet still crispy delight, and the meatloaf, although relatively plain ingredients-wise, was moist and flavorful. I was so glad I ordered the Hanger Steak, which as usual was the belly cut of the cow that hangs really low hence the name, cooked medium just the way I like it and served with its own juicy marinade and plenty of fresh veggies like onions and greens. It was a feast for the eyes and mouth thanks the amount of food that was on my plate and how well prepared the dish was. We were all thoroughly satisfied after feasting on our entrees.

    But of course we still had our dessert course to go, with choices of their Key Lime Pie, Chocolate Hazelnut Semifreddo, and their Butterscotch Pudding with Pecan Brittle, I went with the latter while others opted for the pie, the dessert chef was so frazzled with so many orders all night long thanks to their pre-fix dining deal that he left us with five desserts, two pies, two puddings and one semifreddo despite only being four of us at our table. Talk about taking the extra steps to make sure we were all full! I loved the hint of booze in my butterscotch pudding which was perfectly presented and not too sweet, as were the pie and semifreddo which was a fun spin on an ice cream cake with whipped cream.

    Blue Plate you made our Restaurant Week experience one to remember. Great service and a solid variety of food at affordable prices set in an old-school atmosphere. I can't wait to return to try some dishes off of their a la carte menu, thanks to SFRW, we got a great sample of at least three of their six large plates that and their variety of smaller plates makes me want to come back for more!

    See all photos from Jason F. for Blue Plate

    Share review

    Embed review

    2/9/2019

    8 photos

    Our first week in the bay area, we decided to check out Blue Plate on a recommendation from a coworker to celebrate and congratulate ourselves on a move well-finished. We were a bit late thanks to a delay on BART, but when we told the hostess that we had a reservation and were running late, we were still seated immediately.

    We were greeted quickly by our waiter, Cal, who was very friendly and personable with an approachable character that put us immediately at ease, and had us laughing and joking around even before we started drinking. He made perfect wine recommendations, and when I requested a sweeter Pinot, he recommended two different bottles. The one we chose based on his recommendation was perfect.

    We ordered two appetizers (Brandade Gnocchi and Smoked Beets and Burrata), two entrees (Hangar Steak and Meatloaf), two side dishes (Macaroni and Spanish Drunken Goat Cheese and the Brussels Sprouts), and split a Key Lime Pie for dessert.Blue Plate also serves homemade Focaccia bread while you order and wait for your meals.

    Focaccia: We honestly could have just ordered a bottle of wine and eaten our fill of the focaccia, it was so good. In fact, I blame this for us not being able to finish our meals when they arrived - but I would absolutely do it again.

    Brandade Gnocchi: The gnocchi in this dish were perfectly light and fluffy, and the duck confit had a great flavor and complemented the dish well. Absolutely delicious.

    Smoked Beets and Burrata: I loved this dish, though beets are hit or miss for my partner and he didn't enjoy it. The smoked beets were hands down the best beets I had ever eaten, and the buratta and greens helped immensely to cut through the smokiness.

    Hangar Steak: The steak was cooked perfectly to medium rare as I had requested, and the romesco sauce and greens were very fresh and complemented the steak well.

    Meatloaf: Hands down the best meatloaf I've ever tasted. I was a bit skeptical of this dish, because I've never loved meatloaf, but when I tried my partners, I was absolutely blown away. The accompanying mashed potatoes were also perfectly light and smooth.

    Macaroni and Spanish Drunken Goat Cheese: Besides being scorching hot - of which we were warned - this macaroni and cheese was perfectly balanced, and was a great side.

    Brussels Sprouts: I originally expected the eggplant to be in pieces with the brussels sprouts, but instead they were pureed with the tasso and honey into the sauce which adorned the plate, and actually provided a great foil to the sprouts. Not at all what I was expecting, but great!

    Key Lime Pie: One of my favorite desserts anyway, this key lime pie was amazing. It wasn't overwhelming with key lime flavor like many store-bought or food-service brand key lime pies, instead opting for a more mellow flavor, and a much lighter custard filling.

    Word to the wise, the portions are relatively large for the appetizers and entrees. We could have done with only one appetizer, or only one side, and we had to take some of our meals home at the end of the night - not entirely a bad thing, since we're now munching through them with our breakfast the next morning! We will definitely be back!

    See all photos from Jason S. for Blue Plate
